\section{A Review of Extriangulated Categories}

\subsection{Axioms of Extriangulated Categories}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{The Axioms of Extriangulated Categories (ET1)}
	\begin{definition}[Extriangulated Category]
		An \textbf{extriangulated category} (\cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019}) is a triplet $(\mathcal{C}, \mathbb{E}, \mathfrak{s})$ satisfying the axioms (ET1)-(ET4). $\mathcal{C}$ is an additive category.
		\begin{itemize}
			\item[ET1] $\mathbb E : \mathcal{C} ^{\mathrm{op}} \times \mathcal{C} \to \mathbf{Ab}$ is an additive bifunctor sending a pair of objects $(C,A)$ to an abelian group $\mathbb{E}(C,A)$.
			\item Elements in $\mathbb E$-groups are called \textbf{extension elements}.
			\item We write $f_\ast$ for the natural transformation $\mathbb E(-,f)$ and $f^\ast$ for $\mathbb E(f,-)$ dually. Bifunctoriality shows $f_\ast g^\ast = g^\ast f_\ast$.
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{C'} \& {\mathbb E(C',A)} \& {\mathbb E(C',A')} \& A \\
	C \& {\mathbb E(C,A)} \& {\mathbb E(C,A')} \& {A'}
	\arrow["{\alpha_\ast}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\gamma^\ast}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\gamma^\ast}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=2-1, to=1-1]
	\arrow["{\alpha_\ast}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
			\item A \textbf{morphism of extension elements} is a pair $(\alpha;\gamma) : \delta \to \delta'$ s.t. $\alpha_\ast \delta = \gamma^\ast \delta'$.
		\end{itemize}
	\end{definition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{The Axioms of Extriangulated Categories (ET2)}
	\begin{itemize}
		\item[ET2] $\mathfrak{s}$ is a collection of ``maps'' known as an \textbf{additive realisation}
			\begin{equation*}
				\mathbb{E}(C,A) \to [A \xrightarrow{x} B \xrightarrow{y} C],\quad \delta \mapsto \mathfrak{s}(\delta).
			\end{equation*}
			Here $[A \xrightarrow{x} B \xrightarrow{y} C]$ is an equivalence class of sequences $A \xrightarrow{x} B \xrightarrow{y} C$ in $\mathcal{C}$ under the relation
			\begin{equation*}
				(A \xrightarrow{x} B \xrightarrow{y} C) \sim (A \xrightarrow{\varphi x} B' \xrightarrow{y\varphi ^{-1}} C),\quad \varphi : B \cong B'.
			\end{equation*}
			\item ``Additive'' means that $\mathfrak{s}(0_{C,A}) = [A \xrightarrow{\binom 10}A \oplus C \xrightarrow{(0,1)}C]$, and $\mathfrak{s}$ sends direct sums in $\mathbb E$-groups to direct sums of sequences.
			\item Moreover, a morphism of extension elements $(\alpha;\gamma) : \delta \to \delta'$ is sent by $\mathfrak{s}$ to a \textbf{morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations} $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$:
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = small]
	\delta \& {\mathfrak s(\delta)} \& A \& B \& C \\
	{\delta'} \& {\mathfrak s(\delta')} \& {A'} \& {B'} \& {C'}
	\arrow["{\mathfrak s}", maps to, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{(\alpha;\gamma)}"', from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\ni }"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["f", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=1-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["g", from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow["\beta", dashed, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["{\mathfrak s}", maps to, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\ni }"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f'}", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=2-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow["{g'}", from=2-4, to=2-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
	\end{itemize}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{The Axioms of Extriangulated Categories (ET3, ET3$^{\mathrm{op}}$)}
	\begin{definition}[$\mathbb E$-conflations]
		We write $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z \overset \delta \dashrightarrow$ if $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z$ belongs to $\mathfrak{s} (\delta)$. 
		\begin{itemize}
			\item We call such a sequence an \textbf{$\mathbb E$-conflation}, 
			\item $f$ (or $g$) is called an \textbf{$\mathbb E$-inflation} (or \textbf{$\mathbb E$-deflation}).
			\item A morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations is a triplet $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ s.t. 
			\begin{equation}\label{eq:morphism-of-E-conflations}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = small]
	A \& B \& C \& {\,} \\
	{A'} \& {B'} \& {C'} \& {\,}
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["\beta", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\alpha_\ast \delta = \gamma^\ast \delta'}", draw=none, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{f'}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{g'}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\delta'}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation}
		\end{itemize}
	\end{definition}

	\begin{itemize}
		\item[ET3] Let $f$ and $f'$ be $\mathbb E$-inflations. Any $\beta f = f'\alpha$ extends to (\ref{eq:morphism-of-E-conflations}).
		\item[ET3$^{\mathrm{op}}$] Let $g$ and $g'$ be $\mathbb E$-deflations. Any $\gamma g = g'\beta$ extends to (\ref{eq:morphism-of-E-conflations}).
	\end{itemize}

	\begin{remark}
		ET2, ET3 and ET3$^{\mathrm{op}}$ shows that $(\alpha; - ; \gamma)$, $(\alpha; \beta; -)$ and $(-; \beta; \gamma)$ complete to morphisms of $\mathbb E$-conflations under suitable conditions.
	\end{remark}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{The Axioms of Extriangulated Categories (ET4, ET4$^{\mathrm{op}}$)}
	\begin{itemize}
		\item[ET4] Given any two $\mathbb E$-conflations
		\begin{equation*}
			A \xrightarrow{f} B \xrightarrow{g} C \overset \delta \dashrightarrow,\quad B \xrightarrow{u} D \xrightarrow{v} F \overset {\varepsilon} \dashrightarrow,
		\end{equation*}
		there exists a commutative diagram of four $\mathbb E$-conflations
\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \& B \& C \& {\, } \\
	A \& D \& E \& {\,} \\
	\& F \& F \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\, }
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{u'}", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(u')^\ast \delta' = \delta}", draw=none, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{f'}", dashed, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["v", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta'}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{v'}", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{(v')^\ast \varepsilon = f_\ast \delta'}"{pos=1}, draw=none, from=2-4, to=3-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon '}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["{g_\ast \varepsilon = \varepsilon '}"', draw=none, from=4-2, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}
		To conclude, $(1_A;u;u')$, $(g;g';1_F)$, and $(f;1_D;v')$ are morphisms of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
	\end{itemize}
\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{The Axioms of Extriangulated Categories (ET4, ET4$^{\mathrm{op}}$)}
	\begin{itemize}
		\item[ET4$^{\mathrm{op}}$] Given any two $\mathbb E$-conflations
		\begin{equation*}
			A \xrightarrow{f'} D \xrightarrow{g'} E \overset {\delta'} \dashrightarrow,\quad C \xrightarrow{u'} E \xrightarrow{v'} F \overset {\varepsilon'} \dashrightarrow,
		\end{equation*}
		there exists a commutative diagram of four $\mathbb E$-conflations
\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \& B \& C \& {\, } \\
	A \& D \& E \& {\,} \\
	\& F \& F \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\, }
	\arrow["f", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{u'}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(u')^\ast \delta' = \delta}", draw=none, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{f'}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{g'}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["v", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta'}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{v'}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{(v')^\ast \varepsilon = f_\ast \delta'}"{pos=1}, draw=none, from=2-4, to=3-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon '}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["{g_\ast \varepsilon = \varepsilon '}"', draw=none, from=4-2, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}
		To conclude, $(1_A;u;u')$, $(g;g';1_F)$, and $(f;1_D;v')$ are morphisms of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
	\end{itemize}
\end{frame}

\subsection{Fundamental Results in \texorpdfstring{\cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019}}{Nakaoka et al. (2019)}}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{$6$-term long exact sequences}

We revisit some fundamental results in \cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019}.

\begin{theorem}[Corollary 3.12. in \cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019}]
	For any $\mathbb E$-conflation $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z \overset{\delta}{\dashrightarrow}$, one has the following two exact sequences of functors:
{\small\begin{equation*}
        \mathcal{C}(-, X) \xrightarrow{\mathcal{C}(-, f)} \mathcal{C}(-, Y) \xrightarrow{\mathcal{C}(-, g)} \mathcal{C}(-, Z) \xrightarrow{\delta_\sharp} \mathbb E(-, X) \xrightarrow{f_\ast} \mathbb E(-, Y) \xrightarrow{g_\ast} \mathbb E(-, Z),
    \end{equation*}
    \begin{equation*}
        \mathcal{C}(Z, -) \xrightarrow{\mathcal{C}(g, -)} \mathcal{C}(Y, -) \xrightarrow{\mathcal{C}(f, -)} \mathcal{C}(X, -) \xrightarrow{\delta^\sharp} \mathbb E(Z, -) \xrightarrow{g^\ast} \mathbb E(Y, -) \xrightarrow{f^\ast} \mathbb E(X, -).
    \end{equation*}}
\end{theorem}

\begin{corollary}
	We enumerate some immediate consequences.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item $f$ is a weak kernel of $g$. Dually, $g$ is a weak cokernel of $f$.
		\item Let $(\alpha; \beta; \gamma)$ be a morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. If two of $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are isomorphisms, then so is the third one.
		\item If an $\mathbb E$-inflation is epic, then it must be a retraction. Dually, if an $\mathbb E$-deflation is monic, then it must be a section.
	\end{enumerate}
	
\end{corollary}

\end{frame}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{Base change}
	\begin{theorem}[Proposition 3.15. in \cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019}]
		    Let $A_1 \xrightarrow{f_1} B_1 \xrightarrow{g_1} C \overset{\delta_1}{\dashrightarrow}$ and $A_2 \xrightarrow{f_2} B_2 \xrightarrow{g_2} C \overset{\delta_2}{\dashrightarrow}$ be two $\mathbb E$-conflations. Then there exists a commutative diagram
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& {A_2} \& {A_2} \\
	{A_1} \& E \& {B_2} \& {\,} \\
	{A_1} \& {B_1} \& C \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["n", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{f_2}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["m", dashed, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{(g_2)^\ast \delta_1}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{g_2}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_1}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_1}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{(g_1)^\ast \delta_2}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_1}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\delta_2}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
	such that $m_\ast \delta_1 + n_\ast \delta_2 = 0$.
	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Base change}
\begin{theorem}[Proposition 3.17. in \cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019}]\label{thm:base-change}
    Given three $\mathbb E$-conflations (in solid arrows), there is a way to complete the diagram
	\begin{equation*}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& {A_2} \& {A_2} \\
	{A_1} \& E \& {B_2} \& {\,} \\
	{A_1} \& {B_1} \& C \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["j", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{f_2}", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["i", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["p", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["q", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\eta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{g_2}", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_1}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_1}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_1}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\delta_2}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation*}
    such that $(1_{A_1}; q; g_2)$ and $(1_{A_2}; p; g_1)$ are morphisms of $\mathbb E$-conflations, and $i_\ast (\delta_1) = j_\ast (\delta_2)$.
\end{theorem}

\end{frame}

\section{Homotopic Squares}

\subsection{The Idea of Homotopic Squares}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Section, Retraction, and Retract}
	\begin{definition}[Section, retraction]
		Let $f: A \to B$ be a morphism in any category.
		\begin{itemize}
			\item $f$ is called a \textbf{section} if there exists a morphism $g: B \to A$ such that $g f = 1_A$. (= \textbf{split monic} in some literature).
			\item $f$ is called a \textbf{retraction} if there exists a morphism $h: B \to A$ such that $f h = 1_B$. (= \textbf{split epic} in some literature).
		\end{itemize}
		
	\end{definition}
	\begin{definition}[Retract]
		A morphism $f' : A' \to B'$ is called a \textbf{retract} of a morphism $f: A \to B$, if there exists a commutative diagram 
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{A'} \& A \& {A'} \\
	{B'} \& B \& {B'}
	\arrow["i"', from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{1_{A'}}", curve={height=-12pt}, equals, from=1-1, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{f'}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["p"', from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["f", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{f'}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["j", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{1_{B'}}"', curve={height=12pt}, equals, from=2-1, to=2-3]
	\arrow["q", from=2-2, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
	\end{definition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Definition of Homotopic Squares}
	This concept was from triangulated category (\cite{CM_1993__86_2_209_0}), generalised to $n$-angulated (\cite{Lin2016HomotopyCD}) and extriangulated (\cite{heExtensionsCovariantlyFinite2019}) cases.

	\begin{itemize}
		\item There are several variations of the names in triangulated case, e.g., homotopy Cartesian squares, homotopic pullback and pushout squares, homotopy bicatersian squares, etc. We call them \textbf{homotopic squares} for simplicity.
	\end{itemize}

	\begin{definition}[Definition 3.1. in \cite{heExtensionsCovariantlyFinite2019}]
		A commutative square is called a \textbf{homotopic square}, if its induced $3$-term chain map completes to an $\mathbb E$-conflation.
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:homotopic-square}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = tiny]
	A \& B \\
	\&\& A \& {B \oplus X} \& Y \& {\,} \\
	X \& Y
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\beta", from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\binom f\alpha}", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{(\beta, -u)}", from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["u"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=3-1, to=3-2]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		The left square in (\ref{eq:homotopic-square}) is \textbf{homotopic with extension $\delta$}. The arrow $% https://q.uiver.app/#q=WzAsMixbMCwwLCJcXCwiXSxbMSwwLCJcXCwiXSxbMCwxLCIiLDAseyJzdHlsZSI6eyJib2R5Ijp7Im5hbWUiOiJidWxsZXQgaG9sbG93In19fV1d
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-1, to=1-2]
\end{tikzcd}$ indicates a minus sign in the $\mathbb E$-conflation.
	\end{definition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{Examples of Homotopic Squares}

	\begin{lemma}
		A homotopic square is both a weak pullback and a weak pushout.
		\begin{proof}
			Note that a square is a (weak) pullback iff its induced $3$-term chain map forms a (weak) kernel. Dually for (weak) pushout. 
		\end{proof}
	\end{lemma}

	\begin{example}
		An exact category $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{E})$ ``is'' extriangulated. Then 
		\begin{equation*}
			\text{Homotopic Squares} \ = \  \text{Pullback-Pushout Squares}.
		\end{equation*}
	\end{example}
	\vspace{-5mm}

\begin{example}
	Any $\mathbb E$-conflation forms a homotopic square
{\small	\begin{equation*}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = tiny]
	A \& B \\
	\&\& A \& B \& Y \& {\,} \\
	0 \& C
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "g", from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["f", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["g", from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow[between={0.4}{0.8}, Rightarrow, 2tail reversed, from=0, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation*}}
\end{example}

\end{frame}

\subsection{Homotopic Squares are Everywhere}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{A good completion of $(f;?;1)$}
	
	\begin{theorem}[Proposition 1.20. in \cite{LIU201996}]\label{thm:good-completion-et3-23}
		Let $(f; 1_Z) : \delta \to f_\ast \delta$ be a morphism of extension extension elements. For any realisations of $\delta$ and $f_\ast\delta$, one can find a morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations $(f;g;1_Z)$
	\begin{equation}\label{eq:homotopy-square-et3-23}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	{X'} \& {Y'} \& Z \& {\,}
	\arrow["u", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["v", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["g", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{u'}"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{v'}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_\ast \delta}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd},
	\end{equation}
	such that $X \xrightarrow{\binom{u}{f}} Y \oplus X' \xrightarrow{(g,-u')} Y' \overset{(v')^\ast \delta}\dashrightarrow$ is an $\mathbb E$-conflation.
	\end{theorem}
	We omit the dual version of this result.
	\begin{remark}
		The sign rule: when $v'$ appears in the extension element, then $u'$ has a minus sign in the $\mathbb E$-conflation.
	\end{remark}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{A good completion of $(?;g;1)$}

	\begin{theorem}[Theorem 3.3. in \cite{Kong02072024}]\label{thm:good-completion-et4-23}
		For any $v'g = v$, one can find $f$ such that $(f;g;1_Z)$ is a morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations, and $X \xrightarrow{\binom{u}{f}} Y \oplus X' \xrightarrow{(g,-u')} Y' \overset{(v')^\ast \delta}\dashrightarrow$ is an $\mathbb E$-conflation.
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	{X'} \& {Y'} \& Z \& {\,}
	\arrow["u", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["f", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["v", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{u'}"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{v'}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd},
		\end{equation*}
	\end{theorem}
	We omit the dual version of this result.
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{A good completion of ET4 axiom}
	\begin{proposition}
		Suppose there is a diagram of $\mathbb E$-conflations with solid arrows
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:good-completion-et4-23}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = scriptsize]
	A \& B \& D \& {\,} \\
	A \& C \& F \& {\,} \\
	\& E \& E \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["g"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u"', from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["w", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["uf"', from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["h"', from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["v"', from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\theta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["q", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\eta", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		Then there is a way to complete $D \xrightarrow{w} F \xrightarrow{q} E\overset{\eta}{\dashrightarrow}$ so that
		\begin{enumerate}
			\item it satisfies the conditions of ET4 axiom, and 
			\item $\square$ is homotopic with extension $f_\ast \theta$.
		\end{enumerate}
		Moreover, $w$ can be any completion which satisfies Theorem \ref{thm:good-completion-et4-23}.
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{A good completion of ET4 axiom}
	\begin{proof}
		We take any $w$ as in Theorem \ref{thm:good-completion-et4-23}. There is an $\mathbb E$-conflation
		\begin{equation*}
			B \xrightarrow{\binom{-g}{u}}D \oplus C \xrightarrow{(w,h)} F \overset{f_\ast \theta}\dashrightarrow.
		\end{equation*}
		By ``base change'' (\ref{thm:base-change}), there is way to complete
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = scriptsize]
	\& D \& D \\
	B \& {D\oplus C} \& F \& {\,} \\
	B \& C \& E \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["w", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom {-g}u}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{(w, h)}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(0,1)}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{f_\ast \theta}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["q", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["u", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["v", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["\eta", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
		We show (\ref{eq:good-completion-et4-23}) satisfies ET4. We see $qh = v$, $q^\ast \varepsilon = f_\ast \theta$, and $\eta  =(1,0)_\ast \binom 10_\ast \eta = -(1,0)_\ast\binom{-g}{u}_\ast \varepsilon = g_\ast \varepsilon$.
	\end{proof}
\end{frame}

	For exact categories, any completion of ET4($^{\mathrm{op}}$) and ``(co-)base change'' are good, for $\square$ are pushout-pullback squares (\cite{buhlerExactCategories2010a}).
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{A comparison with ker-coker sequence}
	\begin{theorem}[$6$-term exact sequence]\label{thm:6-term-exact-sequence}
	Let $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z$ be a composable pair of morphisms in an Abelian category. Then there is a $6$-term exact sequence
	\begin{equation*}
		0 \to \ker f \to \ker (gf) \to \ker g \xrightarrow{\mathfrak C} \operatorname{cok} f \to \operatorname{cok} (gf) \to \operatorname{cok} g \to 0.
	\end{equation*}
	The connecting morphism $\mathfrak C$ is the composition of
	\begin{equation*}
		\ker g \twoheadrightarrow \frac{\ker g}{\ker g \cap \operatorname{im} f} \simeq \frac{\ker g + \operatorname{im} f}{\operatorname{im} f}\rightarrowtail \frac{Y}{\operatorname{im} g} \simeq \operatorname{cok} f.
	\end{equation*}
	In diagram: 
\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{A comparison with ker-coker sequence}
	\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, column sep=1.5em,
/tikz/column 1/.style={ column sep=0.7em },
/tikz/column 4/.style={ column sep=0.5em }]
\& {\ker g} \&\& {\operatorname{cok}f} \\
{\ker gf} \&\& Y \&\& {\operatorname{cok}gf} \\
\& X \&\& Z \\
{\ker f} \&\&\&\& {\operatorname{cok}g}
\arrow["{\mathfrak C}", curve={height=-18pt}, from=1-2, to=1-4]
\arrow["k", tail, from=1-2, to=2-3]
\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=3-2]
\arrow[from=1-4, to=2-5]
\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-4, to=3-4]
\arrow[from=2-1, to=1-2]
\arrow["j", tail, from=2-1, to=3-2]
\arrow["p", two heads, from=2-3, to=1-4]
\arrow["g", from=2-3, to=3-4]
\arrow[curve={height=-18pt}, two heads, from=2-5, to=4-5]
\arrow["f", from=3-2, to=2-3]
\arrow["gf", curve={height=24pt}, from=3-2, to=3-4]
\arrow["q", two heads, from=3-4, to=2-5]
\arrow["r", two heads, from=3-4, to=4-5]
\arrow[curve={height=-18pt}, tail, from=4-1, to=2-1]
\arrow["i", tail, from=4-1, to=3-2]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}
	Moreover, $\square$ are pullback-pushout squares.
	\begin{proof}
		Well-known (as a corollary of snake lemma).
	\end{proof}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{A comparison with ker-coker sequence}
	Let $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z$ be a composable pair of morphisms in an extriangulated category.
	\begin{corollary}
		When $f$ and $g$ are both $\mathbb E$-inflations, then so is $gf$. There is a way to complete an $\mathbb E$ $\mathbb E$-conflation $C_f \to C_{gf} \to C_g$ such that $\square$ is homotopic:
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, column sep=2em,
    /tikz/column 3/.style={ column sep=1.5em }]
	\&\& {C_g} \\
	\& Y \&\& {C_{gf}} \\
	X \&\& Z \\
	\&\&\& {C_g}
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["p", from=2-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[curve={height=-18pt}, dashed, from=2-4, to=4-4]
	\arrow["f", from=3-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["gf", curve={height=24pt}, from=3-1, to=3-3]
	\arrow["q", from=3-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["r", from=3-3, to=4-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
	\end{corollary}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{A comparison with ker-coker sequence}
	Let $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z$ be a composable pair of morphisms in an extriangulated category.
\begin{corollary}
	If $gf$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation and $g$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, then $f$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation (\textcolor{red}{not an immediate result}). There is a way to complete an $\mathbb E$-conflation $K_g \to C_f \to C_{gf}$ such that $\square$ is homotopic:
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, column sep=2em,
    /tikz/column 3/.style={ column sep=1.5em }]
	{K_g} \&\& {C_g} \\
	\& Y \&\& {C_{gf}} \\
	X \&\& Z
	\arrow[curve={height=-18pt}, dashed, from=1-1, to=1-3]
	\arrow["k", from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["p", from=2-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["f", from=3-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["gf", curve={height=24pt}, from=3-1, to=3-3]
	\arrow["q", from=3-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
\end{corollary}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Composite $\mathbb E$-Inflations/$\mathbb E$-Deflations}
	We fix a gap in the previous page.
	\begin{proposition}
		If $gf$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation and $g$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, then $f$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation.
		\begin{proof}
			A good completion of ET4 yields
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& \cdot \& \cdot \\
	\cdot \& \cdot \& \cdot \& \cdot \\
	\& \cdot \& \cdot \& \cdot
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["s", dashed, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["f"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-24pt}, from=2-1, to=2-3]
	\arrow["1"', from=2-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["h", dashed, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["p", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["g", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-4, to=3-4]
	\arrow["gf", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
			Since $\square$ is a weak pullback, we see $p$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation and a retraction. In this case, $p$ has a kernel. Now $f = hs$ is a composition of two $\mathbb E$-inflations. Thus, $f$ is also an $\mathbb E$-inflation.
		\end{proof}
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Composite $\mathbb E$-Inflations/$\mathbb E$-Deflations}
	We summarise some composition properties of $\mathbb E$-inflations and $\mathbb E$-deflations.
		\begin{enumerate}
		\item $\mathbb E$-inflations are closed under compositions.
		\item If $gf$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, and $g$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, then $f$ is agian an $\mathbb E$-inflation.
		\item If $f$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then for any $h$ with the same domain as $f$, $\binom gh$ is also an $\mathbb E$-inflation.
		\item If $f_1$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, and there is an $\mathbb E$-conflation
		\begin{equation*}
			X \xrightarrow{\binom {f_1}{f_2}} Y \oplus W \xrightarrow{(g_1,g_2)} Z \dashrightarrow.
		\end{equation*}
		Then $g_2$ is also an $\mathbb E$-deflation.
	\end{enumerate}
\end{frame}

\subsection{Composite/Translate/Split Properties}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Composite Homotopic Squares}
	\begin{theorem}[\cite{HeXieZhou+2023}]
		The composition of two homotopic squares is also homotopic.
		\begin{proof}
			We take the following homotopic squares:
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \& B \& C \\
	D \& E \& F
	\arrow["f"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\boxed \kappa}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["\beta", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed \varepsilon }"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["u", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["v", from=2-2, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
		By ET2, there are isomorphic $\mathbb E$-conflations
\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \& {B \oplus D \oplus C} \&\& {E \oplus C} \& {\,} \\
	A \& {B \oplus D \oplus C} \&\& {E \oplus C} \& {\,}
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{-f\\ \alpha\\0}\right) \end{array}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta \ u \ 0}{0 \ 0 \ 1}}", from=1-2, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{\kappa\oplus 0}", dashed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{-f\\ \alpha\\gf}\right) \end{array}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{1 \ 0 \  0 \\ 0 \ 1 \ 0 \\ g \ 0 \ 1}\right) \end{array}"', from=2-2, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\simeq", draw=none, from=2-2, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta \ u \ 0}{g \ 0 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\kappa\oplus 0}", dashed, from=2-4, to=2-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}
Moreover, $\varepsilon = f_\ast (\kappa\cup \varepsilon)$ and $\kappa = (\kappa\cup\varepsilon)$
		\end{proof}
	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Composite Homotopic Squares}

			By ``base-change'', there is a unique dashed $\mathbb E$-conflation
			\begin{equation}\label{eq:composite-homotopic-square-3}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& B \& B \\
	A \& {B \oplus D \oplus C} \& {E \oplus C} \& {\,} \\
	A \& {D \oplus C} \& F \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{1\\0\\0}\right) \end{array}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\binom \beta g}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{-f\\ \alpha\\gf}\right) \end{array}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta \ u \ 0}{g \ 0 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom{0 \ 1 \ 0}{0 \ 0 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\kappa \oplus 0}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{(v,-\gamma)}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\binom \alpha {gf}}", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{(vu,-\gamma)}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\kappa \cup \varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation}
			This shows $A \xrightarrow{\binom{\alpha}{-gf}}D \oplus X \xrightarrow{(vu,\gamma)} F \overset{\kappa \cup \varepsilon}{\dashrightarrow}$ is an $\mathbb E$-conflation. From (\ref{eq:composite-homotopic-square-3}), we also obtain that
\begin{equation*}
	v^\ast (\kappa \cup \varepsilon) = \kappa,\quad f_\ast (\kappa \cup \varepsilon) = \varepsilon.
\end{equation*}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Composite Homotopic Squares}
	\begin{proposition}
		Let $\boxed{\kappa}$ be homotopic. If $\binom \alpha {gf}$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so is $\binom g\beta$. Consequently, the diagram completes to a composition of homotopic squares.
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:composite-homotopic-square-4}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \& B \& C \\
	D \& E \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}{F}
	\arrow["f"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\boxed \kappa}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["\beta", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed \varepsilon }"{description}, color={rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\gamma", color={rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}, dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["u", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["v", color={rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}, dashed, from=2-2, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		\begin{proof}
			\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \& {B \oplus D \oplus C} \&\& {E \oplus C} \& {\,} \\
	A \& {B \oplus D \oplus C} \&\& {E \oplus C} \& {\,}
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{-f\\ \alpha\\0}\right) \end{array}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta \ u \ 0}{0 \ 0 \ 1}}", from=1-2, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{\kappa\oplus 0}", dashed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{-f\\ \alpha\\gf}\right) \end{array}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{1 \ 0 \  0 \\ 0 \ 1 \ 0 \\ g \ 0 \ 1}\right) \end{array}"', from=2-2, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\simeq", draw=none, from=2-2, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta \ u \ 0}{g \ 0 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\kappa\oplus 0}", dashed, from=2-4, to=2-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}
		\end{proof}
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Composite Homotopic Squares}
	Let $A \xrightarrow{\binom \alpha {gf}}D \oplus C\xrightarrow{(p,-\gamma)} F \overset{\delta}{\dashrightarrow}$ be any $\mathbb E$ $\mathbb E$-conflation induced by $\binom{\alpha}{gf}$. By ``base-change'', there is a some dashed morphism making the following diagram commute:
	\begin{equation*}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& B \& B \\
	A \& {B \oplus D \oplus C} \& {E \oplus C} \& {\,} \\
	A \& {D \oplus C} \& F \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{1\\0\\0}\right) \end{array}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\binom \beta g}", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\begin{array}{c} \left(\substack{-f\\ \alpha\\gf}\right) \end{array}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta \ u \ 0}{g \ 0 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom{0 \ 1 \ 0}{0 \ 0 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\kappa \oplus 0}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{(v,-\gamma)}", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\binom \alpha {gf}}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{(p,-\gamma)}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation*}
	\begin{corollary}
		The completion of \ref{eq:composite-homotopic-square-4} exists if one of $\alpha$, $f$, $\beta$, $u$, $g$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation.
	\end{corollary}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Parallel Edges of Homotopic Squares}
	\begin{theorem}
		We fix any homotopy square:
	\begin{equation*}
% https://q.uiver.app/#q=WzAsNCxbMCwwLCJBXzEiXSxbMSwwLCJCXzEiXSxbMCwxLCJBXzIiXSxbMSwxLCJCXzIiXSxbMCwyLCJmIl0sWzAsMSwidSJdLFsxLDMsImciXSxbMiwzLCJ2Il0sWzAsMywiXFxzcXVhcmUiLDEseyJzdHlsZSI6eyJib2R5Ijp7Im5hbWUiOiJub25lIn0sImhlYWQiOnsibmFtZSI6Im5vbmUifX19XV0=
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{A_1} \& {B_1} \\
	{A_2} \& {B_2}
	\arrow["u", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["v", from=2-1, to=2-2]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation*}
	We have the following statements (and their duals).
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item $u$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation if and only if $v$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation. 
		\item If $v$ is a retraction, then so is $u$. 
		\item If $v$ is a retract of some $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so is $u$.
	\end{enumerate}
	\begin{proof}
		The proof of the first two statements are straightforward by diagram chasing. It is worth mentioning that
		\vspace{-3mm}
		\begin{equation*}
			\text{retracts of $\mathbb E$-inflations} \ = \ \text{retractions}\circ\text{inflations}.
		\end{equation*}
	\end{proof} 
	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Split Homotopic Squares}
	\begin{theorem}
		Suppose the left commutative diagram is a homotopic square. If one the following conditions holds:
		\begin{enumerate}
			\item $u$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation,
			\item $v$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation,
			\item $\gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation.
		\end{enumerate}
		Then there is a way to write $h$ as $gf$ such that the right diagram is a composition of homotopic squares.
\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	A \&\& C \& A \& B \& C \\
	D \& E \& F \& D \& E \& F
	\arrow["h", from=1-1, to=1-3]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[""{name=1, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\gamma", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", dashed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\boxed \varepsilon}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow["g", dashed, from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow["\beta", dashed, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["{\boxed \kappa}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["u"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["v"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["u"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow["v"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{\boxed \tau}"{description}, draw=none, from=0, to=1]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}

	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\subsection{Morphisms are Both \texorpdfstring{$\mathbb E$}{PDFstring}-inflations and \texorpdfstring{$\mathbb E$}{PDFstring}-deflations}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Morphisms are both $\mathbb E$-inflations and $\mathbb E$-deflations}
	\begin{definition}[$S$, $\mathcal{L}$, and $\mathcal{R}$]
		We set $S := (\mathbb E\text{-Inflations}) \cap (\mathbb E\text{-Deflations})$, and 
		\begin{equation*}
			\mathcal{L} = \{X \mid (X \to 0) \in S\}, \quad \mathcal{R} = \{X \mid (0 \to X) \in S\}.
		\end{equation*}
		$S$ is closed under compositions and contains all isomorphisms.
	\end{definition}

	\begin{lemma}
		$S$, $\mathcal{L}$, and $\mathcal{R}$ are mutually determined. 
		\begin{proof}
			The key observation: any $f \in S$ gives $K \to 0 \to C \dashrightarrow$ by
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	K \& X \& 0 \\
	0 \& Y \& C
	\arrow["i", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["f"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["c", from=2-2, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
		\end{proof}
	\end{lemma}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Morphisms are both $\mathbb E$-inflations and $\mathbb E$-deflations}
	\begin{lemma}
		$X \in \mathcal{L}$ iff any $X \xrightarrow{\varphi} T$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation for all $T \in \mathcal{C}$.
		\begin{proof}
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	X \& 0 \& R \& {\,} \\
	T \& E \& R \& {\,}
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{\varphi }"', from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
		\end{proof} 
	\end{lemma}
	\vspace{-5mm}
	\begin{proposition}
		Once we fix for $X \in \mathcal{L}$ an $\mathbb E$-conflation $X \to 0 \to FX \overset {\delta_X} \dashrightarrow$, then
		\begin{enumerate}
			\item $F : \mathcal{L} \to \mathcal{R}$ is an equivalence of full subcategories.
			\item Any $X \in \mathcal{L}$ yields a natural isomorphism in $\mathbf{Fun}(\mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathbf{Ab})$:
			\begin{equation*}
				\theta^{(X)} : \mathcal{C}(-, FX) \simeq \mathbb E(-, X),\quad \varphi \mapsto \varphi^* \delta_X.
			\end{equation*}
			Moreover, $\theta^{(X)}$ is functorial in $X \in \mathcal{L}$.
		\end{enumerate}
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\begin{proposition}
		If $\mathcal{L} = \mathsf{Ob}(\mathcal{C})$, then the category admits a right triangulated structure with suspension functor $F$:
		\begin{equation*}
			\underset{\mathbb E\text{-conflation}}{\underbrace{(X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z \overset {\delta} \dashrightarrow)}} \iff \underset{\text{Distinguished right triangle}}{\underbrace{(X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z \xrightarrow {\theta^{-1}(\delta)} FX)}}.
		\end{equation*}
		\begin{proof}
			We briefly explain the axioms of morphism-embedding and clockwise rotation by homotopic squares.
			\begin{enumerate}
				\item (Morphism embedding) Any $X \xrightarrow{f} Y$ embeds to
				\begin{equation*}
					% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	X \& 0 \& FX \& {\,} \& X \& Y \& E \& {\,} \\
	Y \& E \& FX \& {\,} \& X \& Y \& E \& FX
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_X}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow["{-g}", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow["{h^\ast \delta_X}", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow["g", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["h", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_\ast \delta_X}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["f", from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{-g}", from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["h", from=2-7, to=2-8]
\end{tikzcd}.
				\end{equation*}
				Since $\theta$ is a natural iso, $\theta^{-1}(h^\ast \delta_X) = \theta^{-1}(\delta_X)\circ h = h$.
			\end{enumerate}
		\end{proof}
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\begin{proof}
		\begin{enumerate}
			\item[2.] (Clockwise rotation) Any distinguished right triangle $X \xrightarrow{u} Y \xrightarrow{v} Z \overset {\theta^{-1}(\varepsilon)}\dashrightarrow FX$ admits a clockwise rotation
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \& Y \& Z \& FX \& {\,} \\
	X \& 0 \& FX \& {\,} \& Y \& Z \& FX \& FY
	\arrow["u", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["v", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{-v}", from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow["{u_\ast \delta_X}", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_X}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{-v}", from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["Ff", from=2-7, to=2-8]
\end{tikzcd}
			\end{equation*}
			Here $\gamma$ is uniquely determined. Since $\theta$ is a natural isomorphism, we have $\theta^{-1}(u_\ast \delta_X) = (Fu)\circ \theta^{-1}(\delta_X) = Fu$.
		\end{enumerate}
	\end{proof}

\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
		\frametitle{Morphisms are both E-inflations and E-deflations}

	\begin{remark}
		Clockwise rotation in diagram:
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{X} \& 0 \&\& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,211}{Y} \& 0 \\
	\textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,211}{Y} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,184;green,51;blue,255}{Z} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,153;green,160;blue,255}{{\Sigma X}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,184;green,51;blue,255}{Z} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,51;green,65;blue,255}{{\Sigma X}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,153;green,221;blue,255}{{\Sigma Y}}
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["u", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,129}, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\boxed{w}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow["v", color={rgb,255:red,204;green,51;blue,255}, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\Sigma u}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow[from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["v", color={rgb,255:red,204;green,51;blue,255}, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["w", color={rgb,255:red,170;green,153;blue,255}, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["w", color={rgb,255:red,85;green,51;blue,255}, from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow["{\Sigma u}", color={rgb,255:red,153;green,192;blue,255}, from=2-5, to=2-6]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
	\end{remark}

	\begin{example}
		Not all right triangulated categories arise in this way. Let $\mathcal{A}$ be Abelian with distinguished right triangles $\{X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{\pi}\operatorname{cok} f \to 0\}$. The suspension $0$ is not an isomorphism.
	\end{example}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Happel's Theorems}
	\begin{theorem}\label{thm:happel's-theorems}
		The following shows relations between extriangulated categories and triangulated categories.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item An extriangulated category is triangulated iff $\mathcal{L} = \mathcal{R} = \mathsf{Ob}(\mathcal{C})$.
		\item An extriangulated category is triangulated iff $S = \mathsf{Mor}(\mathcal{C})$.
		\item The ideal quotient $\mathcal{C} / {[\mathcal{B}]}$ is triangulated iff $\mathcal{C}$ is Frobenius with $\mathcal{B}$ the subcategory of projective-injective objects.
		\item Let $(\mathcal{D}, \mathbb F, \mathfrak t) \subseteq (\mathcal{C}, \mathbb E, \mathfrak s)$ be an extriangulated subcategory with $\mathsf{Ob}(\mathcal{C}) = \mathsf{Ob}(\mathcal{D})$. If $(\mathcal{D}, \mathbb F, \mathfrak t)$ is triangulated, then so is $(\mathcal{C}, \mathbb E, \mathfrak s)$.
	\end{enumerate}
	\end{theorem}

	\begin{remark}[A historical remark]
		The third statement in \ref{thm:happel's-theorems} is shown for extension-closed subcategories of triangulated categories (\cite{iyamaMutationTriangulatedCategories2008a}, \cite{Nakaoka2010FrobeniusCO}).
		
		This generalisation motivates the definition of extriangulated categories (\cite{209434}).
	\end{remark}
\end{frame}

\section{Diagram Lemmas}

\subsection{On WIC conditions}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{WIC v.s. Weakly Idempotent Complete}
	\cite{nakaokaExtriangulatedCategoriesHovey2019} introduced a WIC condition for extriangulated categories, serving as a strong version of being weakly idempotent completeness.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item (weakly idempotent complete) every section has a cokernel;
		\item (WIC) if $gf$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so is $f$.
	\end{enumerate}
	The equivalency is shown in \cite{klapproth2023nextensionclosedsubcategoriesnexangulated}. We propose a simple proof and another equivalent condition for establising $3\times 3$-lemmas.

	\begin{theorem}
		An additive category is weakly idempotent complete if and only if the following condition holds: any section has a cokernel; any retraction has a kernel.
	\end{theorem}
	\begin{remark}
		Triangulated categories are automatically WIC. For exact categories, see \cite{buhlerExactCategories2010a}.
	\end{remark}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}\frametitle{WIC v.s. Weakly Idempotent Complete}
	\begin{proposition}
		The following are equivalent for an extriangulated category.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item (weakly idempotent complete) every section has a cokernel;
		\item (WIC) if $gf$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so is $f$.
	\end{enumerate}
	\begin{proof}
		($1 \to 2$). $\binom f 0 = \binom{\ \ 1 \ \  0}{-g \ \ 1} \binom {f}{gf}$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation. We consider
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	X \& {Y\oplus W} \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\& {Z \oplus W}
	\arrow["{\binom f0}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["0"'{pos=0.3}, curve={height=12pt}, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{(s,t)}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom{s \ \ 0}{0 \ \ 1}}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{\binom ab}"{pos=0.3}, curve={height=-12pt}, dashed, from=1-3, to=2-2]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
		Since $bt = 1_W$, $(s,t)$ takes the form $\binom{s_1 \ 0}{s_2 \ 1} : Y\oplus W \to Q \oplus W$ where $Q \simeq \operatorname{cok} t$. By ``base-change'', we obtain
	\end{proof}
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{WIC v.s. Weakly Idempotent Complete}
	\begin{equation*}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& W \& W \\
	X \& {Y\oplus W} \& {Q \oplus W} \& {\,} \\
	X \& Y \& Q \& {\,} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\, }
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 01}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\binom 01}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom f0}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\binom{s_1 \ 0}{s_2 \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(1,0)}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{(1,0)}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["f", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{s_1}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation*}
	($2 \to 1$). Let $p$ be section with right inverse $i$. Since $pi = 1$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, $i$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation by WIC. Hence $i$ has a cokernel. We obtain the structure map of the direct sums.
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Equivalent Conditions for WIC}
	\begin{theorem}
		The following are equivalent for an extriangulated category.
		\begin{enumerate}
		\item (Definition). Any section has a cokernel.
		\item If $\binom i0$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so is $i$.
		\item If $\binom {i \ \ 0}{0 \ \ j}$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so  are $i$ and $j$.
		\item (WIC). If $fi$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then so is $i$.
		\item $\mathbb E$-inflations are closed under retracts.
		\item Any $\circlearrowright$ completes to a $3 \times 3$-diagram
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,} \\
	{C_1} \& {C_2} \& {C_3} \& {\,} \\
	{\,} \& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{i_2}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\circlearrowright"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{p_1}", dashed, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_2}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{p_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_C}", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{g_C}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_C}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _3}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
		\end{enumerate}
	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\begin{proof}
		We show ($6 \to 1$) via $(\text{not} \ 1 \to \text{not} \ 6)$. Let $X \xrightarrow{i} Y$ be a section without cokernel, with $q$ as its right inverse. Consider
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	Y \& {X \oplus Y} \& X \& {\,} \\
	Y \& {X \oplus Y} \& X \& {\,}
	\arrow["{\binom q{1-iq}}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{(0,q)}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom {0 \qquad q }{i \quad 1-iq}^2 = \binom {1  \ 0}{0 \ 1}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\binom 01}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\binom {0 \qquad q }{i \quad 1-iq}}"', from=2-2, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\cong", draw=none, from=2-2, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{(1,0)}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
		The following fails to be a $3 \times 3$-diagram
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	X \& X \& 0 \\
	Y \& {X \oplus Y} \& X \\
	Z \& Y \& X
	\arrow["1", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom  10}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom q{1-iq}}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{(0,q)}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(0,1)}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["1", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["q", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
		$q$ is never an $\mathbb E$-deflation, since it has no kernel.
	\end{proof}
\end{frame}

\subsection{Homotopic morphisms of \texorpdfstring{$\mathbb E$}{PDFstring}-conflations}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Homotopic Morphisms of $\mathbb E$-conflations}
	\begin{definition}[Homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-triangles]
		Say $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-triangles, if there is a decomposition
		\begin{equation*}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = large]
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\ } \\
	A \& M \& Z \& {\,} \\
	A \& B \& C \& {\ }
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\boxed{b^\ast \delta}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["s", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-12pt}, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["a"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["b"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["t", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed{a_\ast \gamma}}"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\alpha_\ast \delta = \gamma^\ast \varepsilon }"{pos=1}, dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["u", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["v", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation*}
	\end{definition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Completing Homotopic Morphisms}
	\begin{theorem}
		Let $(\alpha; \beta; \gamma)$ be a morphism of $\mathbb E$-extensions. Then there exists modifications $(\alpha;\beta;\overline \gamma)$, $(\alpha;\overline \beta;\gamma)$, and $(\overline \alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ which are homotopic morphisms of $\mathbb E$-triangles.
		\begin{proof}
			We obtain $\overline \beta$ and $\overline \gamma$ by 
			\begin{equation*}
				% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\ } \& X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	A \& M \& Z \& {\,} \& A \& M \& Z \& {\,} \\
	A \& B \& C \& {\ } \& A \& B \& C \& {\,}
	\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, color={rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,58}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["s", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,58}, dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\overline \beta}"{pos=0.2}, color={rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,58}, curve={height=-12pt}, dashed, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow[from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow["s", from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-12pt}, from=1-6, to=3-6]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-7, to=2-7]
	\arrow["a", dashed, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["b", dashed, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["t", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,58}, dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, color={rgb,255:red,255;green,51;blue,58}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-5, to=3-5]
	\arrow[from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["t", color={rgb,255:red,51;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=2-6, to=3-6]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, color={rgb,255:red,51;green,51;blue,255}, draw=none, from=2-6, to=3-7]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow["\gamma", color={rgb,255:red,51;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=2-7, to=3-7]
	\arrow["u", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["v", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow[from=3-5, to=3-6]
	\arrow[from=3-6, to=3-7]
	\arrow["\varepsilon", dashed, from=3-7, to=3-8]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}
		\end{proof}
	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\subsection{\texorpdfstring{$3 \times 3$}{PDFstring} Lemmas without WIC}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Completing Homotopic Morphisms}
	\begin{proposition}
		Any morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations is a composition of two homotopic morphisms of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\begin{proof}
			Note that homotopic morphisms are closed under isomorphisms.
			{\scriptsize\begin{equation*}
							% https://q.uiver.app/#
			\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, column sep = scriptsize]
				X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \& X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
				{X \oplus A} \& {Y \oplus B} \& {Z \oplus C} \& {\,} \& {X \oplus A} \& {Y \oplus A} \& Z \& {\,} \\
				{X \oplus A} \& {Y \oplus B} \& {Z \oplus C} \& {\,} \& {X \oplus A} \& {Y \oplus B} \& {Z \oplus C} \& {\, } \\
				A \& B \& C \& {\,}
				\arrow["f", from=1-1, to=1-2]
				\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
				\arrow["g", from=1-2, to=1-3]
				\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
				\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
				\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
				\arrow[draw={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, Rightarrow, dotted, from=1-4, to=1-5]
				\arrow["f", from=1-5, to=1-6]
				\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=1-5, to=2-5]
				\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-5, to=2-6]
				\arrow["g", from=1-6, to=1-7]
				\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=1-6, to=2-6]
				\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
				\arrow[equals, from=1-7, to=2-7]
				\arrow["{\binom {f \ 0}{0 \ u}}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
				\arrow["{\binom {1 \ 0}{\alpha \ 1}}", from=2-1, to=3-1]
				\arrow["\simeq"', draw=none, from=2-1, to=3-1]
				\arrow["{\binom {g \ 0}{0 \ v}}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
				\arrow["{\binom {1 \ 0}{\beta \ 1}}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
				\arrow["\simeq"', draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-2]
				\arrow["{\delta \oplus \varepsilon }", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
				\arrow["{\binom {1 \ 0}{\gamma \ 1}}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
				\arrow["\simeq"', draw=none, from=2-3, to=3-3]
				\arrow[draw={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, Rightarrow, dotted, from=2-4, to=3-5]
				\arrow["{\binom {f \ 0}{0 \ 1}}", from=2-5, to=2-6]
				\arrow[equals, from=2-5, to=3-5]
				\arrow["{(g,0)}", from=2-6, to=2-7]
				\arrow["{\binom {1 \ 0}{0 \ u}}", from=2-6, to=3-6]
				\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-6, to=3-7]
				\arrow[dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
				\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=2-7, to=3-7]
				\arrow["{\binom {f \ 0}{0 \ u}}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
				\arrow["{(0,1)}", from=3-1, to=4-1]
				\arrow["{\binom {g \ 0}{0 \ v}}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
				\arrow["{(0,1)}", from=3-2, to=4-2]
				\arrow["{\delta \oplus \varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
				\arrow["{(0,1)}", from=3-3, to=4-3]
				\arrow["{\binom {f \ 0}{0 \ u}}", from=3-5, to=3-6]
				\arrow["{\binom {g \ 0}{0 \ v}}", from=3-6, to=3-7]
				\arrow["{\delta \oplus \varepsilon }", dashed, from=3-7, to=3-8]
				\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
				\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
				\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
			\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation*}}
			We claim $(\binom 10;\binom 10;\binom 10)$ is a morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. In fact, $\square$ are direct sums of easy $\mathbb E$-conflations. We omit the details.
		\end{proof}
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Completing Homotopic Morphisms}
	\begin{theorem}[Completing Homotopic Morphisms]
		Let $(\alpha; \beta; \gamma)$ be homotopic morphisms of $\mathbb E$-triangles. If $\alpha$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, $\beta$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, then $\gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation.
		
		The full table (black $\implies$ \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{red}):
\begin{equation*}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = tiny]
	\alpha \& \beta \& \gamma \&\& \alpha \& \beta \& \gamma \\
	{\text{Infl}} \& {\text{Infl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{\forall} \&\& {\text{Defl}} \& {\text{Infl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Infl}^{\text{Rtc}}}} \\
	{\text{Infl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Infl}}} \& {\text{Infl}} \&\& {\text{Defl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{??}}} \& {\text{Infl}} \\
	\textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Infl}^{\text{Rtc}}}} \& {\text{Infl}} \& {\text{Infl}} \&\& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Defl}^{\text{Rtc}}}} \& {\text{Defl}} \& {\text{Infl}} \\
	{\text{Infl}} \& {\text{Defl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Defl}}} \&\& {\text{Defl}} \& {\text{Defl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Defl}^{\text{Rtc}}}} \\
	{\text{Infl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{\forall} \& {\text{Defl}} \&\& {\text{Defl}} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Defl}}} \& {\text{Defl}} \\
	\textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{{\text{Infl}}} \& {\text{Infl}} \& {\text{Defl}} \&\& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,255;green,54;blue,51}{\forall} \& {\text{Defl}} \& {\text{Defl}}
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}
	\end{theorem}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\frametitle{Completing Homotopic Morphisms}
	We show a detailed proof of one case.
	\begin{proposition}[$3 \times 3$ lemma in the middle]
			Suppose we have $\mathbb E$-conflations realising $\delta_A$, $\delta_B$, $\varepsilon_1$ and $\varepsilon_3$ with $(i_3)^\ast \delta_B = (i_1)_\ast \delta_A$ in the following diagram:
	\begin{equation}\label{eq:3x3-mid}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,} \\
	{C_1} \& {C_2} \& {C_3} \& {\,} \\
	{\,} \& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{i_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{p_1}", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{p_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_C}", color={rgb,255:red,58;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{g_C}", color={rgb,255:red,58;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_C}", color={rgb,255:red,58;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _3}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}
	\end{equation}
	There is a way to complete this diagram to a $3 \times 3$-diagram.
	\end{proposition}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\begin{proof}
		There is a way to an $\mathbb E$-inflation $i_2$ s.t. $(i_1;i_2;i_3)$ is homotopic:
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:pf-3x3-0}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{j_1}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["s", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["t", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{j_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		Here $j_1$ and $j_2$ are constructed by
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:pf-3x3-1}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, row sep = scriptsize, column sep = small]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \& {B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \& {B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,} \\
	{C_1} \& {C_1} \&\& {\,} \&\& {C_3} \& {C_3} \\
	{\,} \& {\,} \&\&\&\& {\, } \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{j_1}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["s", from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["t", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow["{j_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=1-7, to=2-7]
	\arrow["s", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{p_1}", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["t", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["q", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["{p_3 g_B}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=2-6, to=3-6]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow["{p_3}", from=2-7, to=3-7]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{(f_A)_\ast \varepsilon _1}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-6, to=3-7]
	\arrow["\theta", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=3-6, to=4-6]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _3}", dashed, from=3-7, to=4-7]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}

	\end{proof}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
	\begin{proof}
		We finally take $C_1 \xrightarrow{f_C} C_2 \xrightarrow{g_C} C_3 \overset{\delta_C} {\dashrightarrow}$ as follows:
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:pf-3x3-2}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, sep = scriptsize]
	{A_2} \& {A_2} \\
	E \& {B_2} \& {C_3} \& {\, } \\
	{C_1} \& {C_2} \& {C_3} \& {\,} \\
	{\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{j_1}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{i_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{j_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["q", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{p_3 g_B}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\theta", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_C}", color={rgb,255:red,58;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{(f_A)_\ast \varepsilon _1}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{g_C}", color={rgb,255:red,58;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}", color={rgb,255:red,255;green,58;blue,51}, dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_C}", color={rgb,255:red,58;green,51;blue,255}, dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}
		\end{equation}
		It remains to verify such completion satisfies the condition of a $3 \times 3$-diagram, i.e., $f_Bi_1 = i_2f_A$, $g_Bi_2 = i_3g_A$, $f_Cp_1 = p_2f_B$, $g_Cp_2 = p_3g_B$, $(i_1)_\ast\delta_A = (i_3)^\ast\delta_B$, $(p_1)_\ast\delta_B = (p_3)^\ast\delta_C$, $(f_A)_\ast\varepsilon_1 = (f_C)^\ast \varepsilon_2$, and $(g_A)_\ast\varepsilon_2 = (g_C)^\ast \varepsilon_3$.
	\end{proof}
\end{frame}

	\arrow["\theta", color={rgb,255:red,0;green,122;blue,12}, dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-7, to=3-7]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{f_C}", from=3-5, to=3-6]
	\arrow["{(f_A)_\ast \varepsilon _1}"{pos=0.2}, between={0}{0.7}, dashed, from=3-5, to=4-5]
	\arrow["{g_C}", from=3-6, to=3-7]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}"{pos=0.2}, between={0}{0.7}, dashed, from=3-6, to=4-6]
	\arrow["{\delta_C}", color={rgb,255:red,0;green,122;blue,12}, dashed, from=3-7, to=3-8]
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=4-1, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow["{j_1}", dashed, from=4-2, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=4-3, to=5-3]
	\arrow["s", color={rgb,255:red,0;green,122;blue,12}, from=4-5, to=4-6]
	\arrow[equals, from=4-5, to=5-5]
	\arrow["t", from=4-6, to=4-7]

	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=4-6, to=5-7]

	\arrow["{i_3}", from=4-7, to=5-7]
	\arrow["s", color={rgb,255:red,0;green,122;blue,12}, from=5-1, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{p_1}", color={rgb,255:red,0;green,122;blue,12}, from=5-1, to=6-1]
	\arrow["t", from=5-2, to=5-3]
	\arrow["q", color={rgb,255:red,0;green,122;blue,12}, dashed, from=5-2, to=6-2]

\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation*}

$(p_1)_\ast\delta_B \xlongequal{\text{\text{Buttom Row}}} q_\ast s_\ast\delta_B \xlongequal{\text{\text{Top Right}}} q_\ast (p_3)^\ast\theta = (p_3)^\ast q_\ast \theta \xlongequal{\text{\text{Top Right}}} (p_3)^\ast\delta_C$.
	
\end{frame}

$(g_A)_\ast\varepsilon_2 \xlongequal{\text{Top Left}} t_\ast (j_1)_\ast \varepsilon_2 \xlongequal{\text{\text{Top Right}}} t_\ast (g_C)^\ast \theta = (g_C)^\ast t_\ast \theta \xlongequal{\text{\text{Buttom Row}}} (g_C)^\ast \varepsilon_3$.
